thread.title: Carnival buoyed by rival's profit forecast as China takes to cruises
thread.title_full: Carnival buoyed by rival's profit forecast as China takes to cruises

author: Tara Cunningham
title: Carnival buoyed by rival's profit forecast as China takes to cruises
text:
Carnival buoyed by rival’s profit forecast as China takes to cruises Carnival jumped towards the top of the FTSE 100 after US rival raised its profit forecast Photo: REUTERS By Tara Cunningham , Business Reporter 6:42PM BST 31 Jul 2015 Comments 
Carnival cruised higher after its New York-listed rival raised its profit forecast for the year. 
Miami-based Royal Caribbean Cruises, which had only cut its full-year profit forecasts in April, emerged from choppy waters yesterday, saying bookings in the second-half of the year were higher than the previous year. Although equities have been impacted worldwide by the floundering Chinese stock markets, Royal Caribbean has escaped such woes. Instead, it attributed its improved profit outlook to the fast-growing Chinese market. 
China's stock market crash: five numbers you need to know 
The company said more than 95pc of its cruises in China were booked for the year. While Carnival forecast disappointing earnings for the third quarter, in late June analysts at Deutsche bank upgraded the stock owing the move to growth in the Chinese market also. 
Earlier this year, Carnival declared its intentions to carry half of the expectated one million Chinese cruise passengers this year. The positive outlook had a knock-on effect industry-wide lifting Carnival in afternoon trade by 176p, or 5.2pc, to £35.52. 
In the wider market, the FTSE 100 ended the month in positive territory, advancing 27.41 points to 6,696.28. 
Rolls-Royce motored to the top of Britain’s benchmark index, rising 5.9pc to 794p, after activist investor ValueAct took a 5.44pc stake . Ahead of that news emerging late in the day, brokers had however cut the stock’s target price, with RBC Capital Markets among those to lower it to 760p. 
Robert Stallard, of RBC, said “we don’t see a lot of earnings per share growth potential over the next couple of years”. However, he noted new management may help but for now, he reckons investors will remain underwhelmed by the stock’s performance. 
ITV made gains -up 9.1p to 280.7p - after Liberty Global upped its stake in the television broadcaster to 9.9pc . Analysts at Liberum noted Liberty’s move suggests it thinks a move by another player is likely. 
Meanwhile, Thomas Cook tumbled to the bottom of the mid-cap index - down 6p, or 4.8pc, to 119.9p - after two brokers slashed the stock’s price target. The travel operator warned on Thursday profits would be bruised by about £64m due to the recent attack in Tunisia, concerns about the Greek economy, and foreign currency headwinds. Geopolitical concerns have weighed heavily on the share price this year and as a result, Nomura lowered its target price to 123p from 135p, while Natixis cut it to 145p. 
Antofagasta slipped 2.3pc to 567p as it revealed it will buy 50pc of a copper mine, Zaldivar, in Chile from Barrick Gold for more than $1bn. The miner was also targeted by Goldman Sachs, who cut its target price to 490p from 500p believing Anto’s internal view of the copper price is more optimistic than that of the market. 
Finally, shares in I nterContinental Hotels Group slumped 45p, or 1.6pc, to £26.98. It was the first chance investors had to respond to IHG saying it was not in merger talks with Starwood after the market closed on Thursday night.
